Singapore, May 31 -- America's Sweetheart. This unofficial moniker (which usually refers to young, bubbly and wholesome seeming ladies whom women want to be and men want to introduce to their mothers) was first bestowed upon silent era icon Mary Pickford, a nickname given to her by influential theater owner David Grauman. In a 1918 feature in Photoplay, actor Elliott Dexter gushed, "Mary Pickford absolutely captivated me as she does everyone who goes near her. Her genius, her brilliancy, her charm, her beauty...All of that has only been said two or three thousand times more or less and all of it is true." This just about rightly sums up the qualities that an "America's Sweetheart" should embody.

Since Pickford, a number of actresses has similarly captivated movie audiences worldwide over the decades with their screen presence and persona. Early examples include Shirley Temple in the 1930s, June Allyson in the 1940s, Debbie Reynolds in the 1950s, Audrey Hepburn in the 1960s, and Mary Tyler Moore in the 1970s. In more recent times, Meg Ryan made the label of "America's Sweetheart" all her own in the 1980s, while Julia Roberts and Sandra Bullock shared the title in the 1990s.

In the following decade, it can be argued that two actresses similarly shared the title of "America's Sweetheart" in the 2000s. The first was Jennifer Aniston, while the other was Reese Witherspoon.

EARLY LIFE Laura Jeanne Reese Witherspoon was born on 22 March 1976 in New Orleans, Louisiana. Witherspoon's father, John Draper Witherspoon Snr, was a US Air Force doctor and later, an otolaryngologist in private practice. Her mother, Mary Elizabeth Witherspoon (nee Reese) was a registered nurse.

Witherspoon also has an elder brother, John Draper Witherspoon Jr, who is a real estate agent. Due to her father's overseas military posting, Witherspoon spent the first four years of her life in Wiesbaden, Hesse, Germany. After the stint was over, the family shifted back to Nashville, Tennessee.

Back in the US, Witherspoon attended the Harding Academy and Harpeth Hall School in Nashville. In school, Witherspoon was a self-confessed "huge book dork" and a cheerleader who achieved excellent grades. Coming from an academic family, Witherspoon was always driven to achieve. Raised as an Episcopalian, she also proclaimed much pride over her Southern upbringing. Talking to Los Angeles Times, she once said of her Southern roots, "It bred in me such a sense of family and tradition. It helped me establish a normalcy in life that I hope will stay with me for the long haul."

Witherspoon was exposed to the entertainment industry early in her childhood. At the age of seven, the parents of a friend of hers decided to run an advertisement for their flower shop. Witherspoon was suggested as a model and selected. The gig sparked her interest in acting and she began taking acting lessons. At the age of 11, Witherspoon took first place in the 10 State Talent Fair and by the time she was 13, she had already appeared in many advertisements, including ones for Ames discount stores and Opryland theme park.

MOVIE DEBUT

While Witherspoon's work in TV advertisements drew the attentions of many movie casting directors, her movie debut actually came as a combination of luck and competence. At that time, casting calls were made for extras to be cast in a film that was to be shot locally. The film was The Man in the Moon and it was to be directed by Robert Mulligan, the Oscar nominated director of To Kill a Mockingbird.

Witherspoon's friends were trying out as extras, so she went along and was given some lines to read. Her readings were so impressive that the casting directors immediately flew her to Los Angeles for a screen test. Within a month, Witherspoon was cast as one of the movie's leads. Witherspoon then decided to take her mother's maiden name as her stage name as it rolled off the tongue more easily.

The Man in the Moon was a wonderful debut for Witherspoon. Her performance was illuminating. In the movie, she played Dani Trant, a 14-year-old country girl tomboy who falls in love for the first time with her 17-year-old neighbour, Court (played by Jason London). However, things get complicated when Court meets Dani Trant's older sister (played by Emily Warfield) and falls in love with her instead.

Witherspoon's debut performance was touching and mature beyond expectations. Noted critic Roger Ebert praised her acting which "do justice to the slightest nuance of the scene", while Washington Post's Rita Kempley noted Witherspoon's "plucky" performance. Indeed, the precocious Witherspoon was so good, even her fellow cast members were impressed by her work. Tess Harper, who played Witherspoon's character's mother, revealed that the cast had called Witherspoon Little Meryl. For her debut role, Witherspoon was nominated for a Young Artist Award in the category of Best Young Actress.

MAJOR BREAKTHROUGH

Despite her excellent big screen debut, Witherspoon's movie career did not immediately take off. Over the next few years, she took on a number of roles in a couple of TV movies, a TV mini-series and a few movie roles that went largely unnoticed, which included A Far Off Place, Jack the Bear (both 1993) and S.F.W. (1994).

It was only in 1996 when Witherspoon finally got a couple of major breakthroughs. Freeway, a modern take on the Grimm Brothers' classic Little Red Riding Hood, was lauded for a pair of outstanding performances by Witherspoon and her co-star Kiefer Sutherland. Roger Ebert commended that Witherspoon was "as focused and tightly wound here as a young Jodie Foster." Likewise Reelviews' James Berardinelli noted that Witherspoon "captivates with her nonstop energy, culling our sympathy and enabling us to see the world through Vanessa's (her character) eyes."

The other major breakthrough for Witherspoon came in the form of the thriller Fear. Fear was a modest hit, taking in about US$20 million and was far more noted for launching Mark Wahlberg's movie career. However, Witherspoon played no small part in the movie's success and the film turned Witherspoon into a budding major movie starlet.

CRUEL INTENTIONS

After Fear, Witherspoon's next work came two years later in Twilight (1998). Dominated by a core of veteran movie stars including Paul Newman, Susan Sarandon, Gene Hackman and James Garner, Witherspoon's performance as Hackman's sexpot daughter was overshadowed. However, her next role in the technically revolutionary social satire Pleasantville (1998) will not be easily forgotten.

Pleasantville, regarded by many as one of 1998's best films, is about a pair of 90s kids who get magically transported into a 1950s TV sitcom, and slowly but surely introduces colour and character into its formerly monochrome and bland world. Witherspoon's character, Jennifer, is the one who primarily advances revolutionary ideas into this black and white world. New York Times' Janet Maslin noted on her "deliciously naughty performance" while Berardinelli praised that Witherspoon got to "play the bad girl/good girl dual role, and is effective as both." The movie was not a box office smash, but it received three Oscar nominations and remains a well-known cult classic to this day.

Witherspoon's next project was more conventional major movie fare. It was also her biggest hit at that time. Cruel Intentions (1999) is a modern teenage remake of 1988's classic Dangerous Liaisons. It was noted for starring three of the hottest young stars of the day: Witherspoon, Sarah Michelle Gellar and Ryan Phillippe.

While Gellar and Phillippe landed the juicier roles of a pair of devious, manipulative and sexually charged step-siblings, it is arguable that Witherspoon's performance as the virginal, innocent pawn is the hardest to pull off. Cruel Intentions brought in over US$75 million worldwide. It is also one of the best well-remembered teenage dramas of the 1990s.

OFFBEAT CHOICES

Witherspoon's next role was the complete opposite of her virtuous, suffering character in Cruel Intentions. As Tracy Flick, an ambitious, overtly good-natured but privately bitchy and manipulative high school overachiever running for school president, Witherspoon's performance in director Adrian Payne's sharp teenage comedy cum social satire Election (1999) is uproarious fun. For her impressive performance in Election, Witherspoon earned her first major acting award nomination when she was nominated for Best Performance by an Actress in a Motion Picture - Comedy or Musical at the Golden Globes. The film was also nominated for the Best Adapted Screenplay Oscar.

Witherspoon continued to make risky choices over the next couple of years, notably taking on a role in the violent and highly controversial American Psycho (2000), a screen adaptation of the equally controversial same-named novel. The movie, about a hedonistic high-rolling banker who is also a serial killer, was loved by critics and became a cult hit. While the film was centred on a fearless performance by Christian Bale, Witherspoon's supporting performance as the protagonist's fiance is also a highlight among a sea of worthy supporting performances.

Beyond American Psycho, Witherspoon also had a short but memorable cameo in the Adam Sandler comedy Little Nicky (2000). In a movie that was heavily savaged by critics, Witherspoon's walk-on part was a rare bright spot. Playing the title character's angel mum, the indestructible Witherspoon provided the very definition of a bubbly personality. In a movie about the devil's spawn, Witherspoon's performance provided a little slice of comedic heaven.

LEGALLY BLONDE

On hindsight, it is easy to see how Witherspoon's captivating cameo in Little Nicky is a tidy encapsulation of her signature role in Legally Blonde (2001). As the bubbly and simple minded Elle Woods, Witherspoon is the star in a tale about a sorority girl who follows her ex to Harvard Law School to win him back. Exuding immense likeability and immeasurable sunshine, her star power helped rake in over US$140 million at box offices worldwide. While Legally Blonde did not generate the same level of great enthusiasm from critics, Witherspoon's iconic performance was universally praised. She also earned her second Golden Globe nomination for Best Performance by an Actress in a Motion Picture - Comedy or Musical for her iconic performance. The movie also marked the start of a highly successful franchise, with a second sequel currently under pre-production.

The success Witherspoon enjoyed with Legally Blonde catapulted her into superstardom. Her comedic gold dust became highly sought after as she enjoyed a couple of smash hits soon after.

Sweet Home Alabama, a 2002 movie about a young New York City socialite who returns home to Alabama to obtain a divorce from her husband after years of separation, was another vehicle that was tailor made for Witherspoon's warmth, charm and wit. Ebert praised that Witherspoon is "the best reason to see Sweet Home Alabama", while San Francisco Chronicle's Jonathan Curiel wrote that Witherspoon "shows she's a viable actress who can stretch into a role and do funny, sad and sassy." The film took in over US$180 million worldwide.

Similarly, Legally Blonde 2: Red, White and Blonde (2003) also earned over US$100 million worldwide. This sequel, which came a mere 2 years after the original hit, sees Witherspoon's character Elle Woods head to Washington, D.C. to join the staff of a Representative seeking to pass a bill to ban animal testing. Legally Blonde 2 was also Witherspoon's producing debut. She became a more prominent TV and movie producer later in her career.

OSCAR WINNER

Walk the Line, a 2005 biopic about legendary country singer Johnny Cash's early life and his long-time romance with his wife June Carter, was the movie that announced Witherspoon's status as a serious thespian. For her considerable performance as June Carter, Witherspoon swept all the major acting awards there was to win that year, including the Oscar (which was also her first Oscar nomination), the BAFTA Award, the Screen Actors Guild Award and the Golden Globe for Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role. Critics were blown away by Witherspoon's work in Walk the Line, still considered to be among her best to date.

Roger Ebert noted that Witherspoon's performance added "boundless energy" to the film, while James Berardinelli praised that Witherspoon "gives one of her finest performances in years." Rolling Stones' Peter Travers lauded that "her portrayal of June is astounding in its vitality and richness." Meanwhile, San Francisco Chronicle's Mick LaSalle was even more gushing in his praise, noting that "a whole review could be eaten up talking about what's great about Witherspoon in Walk the Line" and then devoting entire paragraphs doing just that.

Walk the Line was a game changer for Witherspoon. It showed that she was not just a great comedian, but also a titan in dramatic acting. The film's critical and commercial success (Walk the Line grossed over US$185 million worldwide) also opened more doors for her to explore other types of roles.

Over the next few years, Witherspoon continued to dabble in dramas, while focusing on her core strength of comedy. She enjoyed a string of US$100 million comedy hits, including Just Like Heaven (2005), Four Christmases (2008) and This Means War (2012). She also helped to bring in over US$100 million for the romantic drama Water for Elephants (2011). Her other noteworthy dramatic offerings during this period included 2007's thriller Rendition (with Jake Gyllenhaal) and 2012's Mud (with Matthew McConaughey).

SECOND OSCAR NOMINATION

In October 2011, Witherspoon saw an advanced copy of the book Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail, five months before its release. The book was mailed personally to Witherspoon by the book's author Cheryl Strayed, who thought that the Oscar-winning actress was the perfect choice to portray her in a film adaptation. Witherspoon read the book and immediately saw potential in a film adaptation. She then acquired the filming rights for her film production label.

Three years later, Wild came out. Directed by Dallas Buyers Club's Jean-Marc Vallee, Wild was a labour of love for Witherspoon as she both produced and starred in the film. There is no doubting Witherspoon's fierce commitment to the project. As noted by film critic James Berardinelli, "She goes all out and, as a result, brings Cheryl vividly to life. There may not be a more committed female performance in a 2014 film. This isn't just Oscar-bait; it's evident that Witherspoon believes in what she's doing here." USA Today's Claudia Puig was in agreement, echoing that "Witherspoon brings writer Strayed alive, with all her complexity, confusion and drive. She makes it impossible not to admire her determination."

With the effusive critical praise which came her way for her committed performance in Wild, it was no surprise when Witherspoon received her second Oscar nomination for Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role as well as nominations for Best Actress at the BAFTA Awards and the Golden Globes. Although she did not win these awards, her success with Wild cemented her increasing reputation as an outstanding movie producer.

PRODUCER AND TV STAR

While Witherspoon primarily made her name as a movie star, it should be noted that at the beginning of her career, she had dabbled briefly in TV work. Thus, her shift towards working in television more extensively did not come as a surprise. Most of her films that followed Wild were not commercial successes. While The Good Lie and Inherent Vice (both 2014) were arthouse pictures and thus had limited commercial appeal, her comedic offerings also did not take off. These included Hot Pursuit (2015) where Witherspoon also served as the producer; Home Again (2017); and the US$100 million Disney blockbuster A Wrinkle in Time (2018) which co-starred Oprah Winfrey, but barely clawed back its costs.

At around 2017, Witherspoon started producing and starring in hit cable TV series Big Little Lies where she found new success. The HBO series, about the lives of upper-class mothers unravelling when a single mother moves into their quaint Californian beach town, was a critical and ratings success. Created by David E. Kelley of Ally McBeal fame, the series, which co-starred Nicole Kidman, Shailene Woodley, Zoe Kravitz and Laura Dern, won a number of Primetime Emmys, Screen Actors Guild Awards and Golden Globes during its successful two season run. Witherspoon was also nominated for a Golden Globe under Best Performance by an Actress in a Limited Series or a Motion Picture Made for Television in 2018 for her role as Madeline Martha Mackenzie in the series.

After her success with Big Little Lies, Witherspoon also produced other TV series like reality series Master the Mess, documentary series Shine On with Reese, Hulu mini-series Little Fires Everywhere (which she also starred in) and Apple TV+ series Truth Be Told. Her next major TV success came in the form of Apple TV+ series, The Morning Show. The drama series, about a fictional popular breakfast news program, was inspired by noted CNN anchor Brian Stelter's book Top of the Morning: Inside the Cutthroat World of Morning TV. The series, which was recently renewed for a third season, was also a ratings and critical success like Big Little Lies. For her role as Bradley Jackson in the series, Witherspoon received a Golden Globe nomination for Best Performance by an Actress in a Television Series - Drama in 2020.

PERSONAL LIFE

Witherspoon has had a somewhat colourful dating history. Her first rumoured boyfriend was fellow actor Jeremy Sisto, her co-star in the 1992 TV movie Solomon's Choice. She had also reportedly dated both Chris O'Donnell and S.F.W. co star Stephen Dorff briefly before meeting her first husband, Ryan Phillippe.

While many people had believed that Witherspoon and Phillippe met during the shooting of their 1999 film Cruel Intentions, the pair had actually met earlier during her 21st birthday party in March 1997. In fact, the pair had become engaged in December 1998 and had been living together for about a year and a half before filming the movie together. The celebrity couple then got married in June 1999. A mere three months after their nuptials, Witherspoon gave birth to daughter Ava Elizabeth Phillippe on 9 September 1999. They also have a son, Deacon Reese Phillippe, who was born on 23 October 2003.

During the time when they were together, Witherspoon and Phillippe were viewed as one of Hollywood's most beloved couples. However, there were subtle signs of trouble during their time together. For example, during the 74th Oscars in 2002 when they were co-presenting an award, Phillippe gestured to the envelope and joked, "You open it. You make more money than I do" when Witherspoon asked if she could read the winner. Nearly two decades later, Witherspoon admitted that she was "flummoxed" by the remark. "I forgot that ever happened. He did say that, and no, it wasn't scripted. He didn't tell me he was going to say that before it happened on air," she explained.

In October 2006, Witherspoon and Phillippe officially announced their separation, and Witherspoon filed for divorce in November 2006, citing irreconcilable differences. During that time, Phillippe had been accused of cheating on Witherspoon with his movie co-star Abbie Cornish. However, Phillippe vigorously denied the allegations, saying "I'm not a perfect person, but I'm not guilty of a lot of the things I have been accused of. My priority is and always has been the health and safety of my family." The couple's marriage officially ended in October 2007, with Phillippe and Witherspoon sharing joint custody of their children.

Witherspoon's failing personal life ironically coincided with her sky-rocketing acting career. It came soon after one of Witherspoon's greatest successes: her Oscar win for Walk the Line. During her emotional acceptance speech, she had thanked Phillippe, saying: "I want to say thank you to my wonderful husband and my two children, who should be going to bed. And thank you for loving me so much and supporting me."

In March 2007, while she was separated from her husband, Witherspoon started seeing actor Jake Gyllenhaal, whom she had met on the set of the 2007 film Rendition. The couple started dating privately and after Witherspoon's divorce was finalized in late 2007, she and Gyllenhaal went public with their relationship. Unfortunately, this relationship only lasted two years and the pair broke up in December 2009.

In February 2010, Witherspoon was reported to be dating Jim Toth, a talent agent and co-head of motion picture talent at Creative Artists Agency, where she is a client. The couple later announced their engagement in December 2010 and married in March 2011. The couple have a son together, Tennessee James Toth, who was born on 27 September 2012.

PHILANTHROPY

Witherspoon has always been on the lookout for opportunities to make a difference. While she has firmly established herself in Tinseltown, her charity work has not gone unnoticed.

Witherspoon is a longtime supporter of Save the Children, an organization that helps provide children around the world with education, healthcare and emergency aid. She also serves on the board of the Children's Defense Fund (CDF), a child advocacy and research group. In 2006, she was among a group of actresses who went to New Orleans, Louisiana in a CDF project to publicize the needs of Hurricane Katrina victims. During this trip, she helped open the city's first Freedom School as she met and talked with the children.

In 2007, Witherspoon signed a multi-year agreement to serve as the first Global Ambassador for cosmetics firm Avon Products. She is currently acting as a spokeswoman for Avon and also serves as the honorary chair of the Avon Foundation, a charitable organization that supports women, and focuses on breast cancer research and the prevention of domestic Witherspoon once said, "If I'm going to do something commercial and mainstream and made for the masses, I just believe you can make those kinds of films with quality - and good ideas and good intentions. There's a lot of negativity out there." This has always been her primary motivation in making feel-good comedies where people can get a good laugh and enjoy themselves. Indeed, as she opined, in a world that has been seeing a lot of negativity in recent years, we could all certainly do with more doses of sweetness - sweetness that Reese Witherspoon seems to possess and provide abundantly. Long may that continue.

Meanwhile, UOB, DBS, TPV and ComfortDelgro helped cushion some of the falls.</p><p>At the end of the day, the STI shed 6.92 points to 2,293.97, while the UOB Sesdaq Index, which was up at midday, finished 0.15 point down to 80.96.</p><p>Keppel Corp fell 2.4 per cent despite saying its operations at its American yard in the Gulf of Mexico were unaffected by Hurricane Katrina. However, according to Reuters, dealers said investors were worried about a slowdown in new orders after the world's top offshore rig builder's order book almost doubled in the first eight months of the year.</p><p>In contrast, SembCorp Marine, the world's number-two offshore oil rig builder, had a better fortune on the market yesterday. Its shares rose as much as 4.3 per cent to hit a record high of $3.10, before pulling back to $3.02 for a gain of five cents or 1.7 per cent.</p><p>Nomura Securities initiated research on the stock with a 'buy' rating. 'With oil prices strong… we expect further, new rig building orders to emerge,' its analyst Lisa Lee wrote in a research note. The company's ability to increase its capacity is also a positive factor, said another analyst.</p><p>Meanwhile, Singapore Telecom, which derived a significant portion of its revenues and earnings from Australia, shed three cents or 1.1 per cent after Australia's dominant operator Telstra said it expected its operating income to decline by as much as 10 per cent due to a fall and slowing growth in its fixed-line and mobile markets, respectively.</p><p>Again, the small competitors in the same sector fared better. MobileOne and MediaRing both chalked up good gains amidst active trading. M1 rose four cents to $2.10 and was the most actively traded stock yesterday with 53.1 million shares changing hands. MediaRing, on the other hand, surged 14 per cent to 24.5 cents on a volume of 38.3 million shares.</p><p>Excluding warrants, declining stocks outnumbered advancers by 209 to 115. Some 785 million Singapore dollar shares worth $820 million were traded.</p><p>On the earnings front, CIMB-GK Goh said that for the quarter ended June 2005, net earnings for the stocks under its coverage rose 8.8 per cent year-on-year. It is maintaining its earnings growth forecasts of 5 per cent for this year and 7.4 per cent for 2006.</p><p>'The market is fairly valued, trading at 13.6 times FY05 price/earnings against earnings growth of only 4.9 per cent for FY05,' it said. 'With several risks threatening to derail the market, we would advocate nimble stock selection.'</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata 'The more repairs and upgrades that need to be done, the more money we will make.'</p><p nitf:lede="true">This seems to be the reasoning behind some brokers' decision to be optimistic about some of the companies in the sector, especially as some of the proxy names are seen to be gaining from oil companies' need to repair their oil rigs in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in the US.</p><p>On Sept 1, UOB Kay Hian said it is maintaining its 'buy' recommendation on Keppel Corp, Singapore's biggest builder of oil rigs.</p><p>'High oil price is positive for the global E&P market, although as oil price increases, fear of its impact on the world economy will increase,' the brokerage said. 'The rig market currently is very tight and the supply shortage will get worse.'</p><p>The market pushed the stock up, and it closed 60 cents, or 5.2 per cent, higher at $12.20 that day. UOB Kay Hian has a target price of $14.50 and thinks that the current 'price weakness' is a good opportunity to buy.</p><p>The local brokerage's report came a day after Credit Suisse First Boston sent out a rather harsh research note which basically said that Keppel has been underperforming and, in its view, will continue to do so; the fair value of the share is 'just $9.62 per share'.</p><p>'For example, a jack-up rig order adds only about 3 cents per share in value to shareholders - even if you ignore the time value of money,' analysts Bradley Burch and Clarice Khoo wrote. 'The record order book of 22 jack-ups and two deepwater rigs (to be delivered over several years) is worth less than $1 per share to shareholders.'</p><p>To justify Keppel's current valuations, Keppel's rig business would need to deliver 'the equivalent of about 17 jack-up rigs each year, every year, forever, starting next year'.</p><p>'That is impossible, in our view,' they wrote.</p><p>Keppel's stock is up 40 per cent since the beginning of the year.</p><p>SembCorp Marine, another big rig builder, added nine cents, or 5 per cent, over the week to close at $2.97 on Friday - just five cents shy of its 12-month high of $3.02, reached last month after its results announcement.</p><p>Various media have reported that at least 20 offshore rigs or platforms have gone missing, have sunk or been set adrift. 'SembCorp Marine is better (than Keppel) … because it has more potential to increase capacity, as it is currently negotiating to use land now occupied by its parent SembCorp's other subsidiaries,' a Daiwa analyst said. SembCorp Marine runs about 13 shipyards globally.</p><p>CIMB-GK Goh Stockbrokers has an 'outperform' rating on SembCorp Marine stock and a price target of $3.38.</p><p>OCBC Investment Research also likes the stock, and thinks the share has a fair value of about $3.22.</p><p>Other Singapore-listed companies which provide shipping services and offshore support have also been reporting good results and may benefit from the increased rig building and repair activity, if that materialises. Labroy Marine posted a 58.5 per cent jump in first-half earnings, while Chuan Hup Holdings reported full-year earnings of US$58.2 million, up 56 per cent. CIMB-GK Goh recommends buying the stock.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H0K-GVC0-0002-M37S-00000-00<published>2005-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>xnetmain</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Stock market hit by oil fears;<br/>Investors take to sidelines to await news of impact of hurricane Katrina on Wall Street and the oil market</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Ven Sreenivasan</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MARKET sentiment was dragged down as US oil prices rose to new record levels as that country braced for a major storm blowing in via the Gulf of Mexico. The Category-5 storm, Katrina, has forced major oil producers and refiners to shut down operations in the Gulf of Mexico, a move which has sent oil prices to its highest levels since the New York Mercantile Exchange began trading oil contracts in 1983. Oil prices hit new record highs in Asian trade yesterday, crossing US$70 a barrel as hurricane Katrina threatened the Gulf of Mexico operations of multinational oil giants like Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp.</p><p>In Singapore, traders said investors took to the sidelines to await the news of the impact of the storm, and its effect on Wall Street and the oil market.</p><p>Already, record high oil prices is raising concern about the corporate earnings of Singapore companies in the current and next quarter. The Straits Times Index started falling from the opening bell, then attempted a weak mid-morning recovery before sliding again. It closed the day with a net 14.55-point loss at 2,272 points as leading blue chips were hit by the prevailing negative news flows. Activity was moderate with some 730 million units worth $685 million changing hands as falls led gainers by 111 to 418, while another 507 counters closed unchanged.</p><p>Jardine Cycle & Carriage was among the more prominent large cap losers on fears that rising oil prices and the removal of fuel subsidies will have considerable impact on the Indonesian economy. It fell 50 cents to $11.20 as analysts assessed the company's exposure to Indonesia. The bulk of its interim earnings for the current year came from its subsidiary PT Astra.</p><p>'With PT Astra contributing more than 80 per cent of group earnings, JCC is exposed to the vagaries of the Indonesian economy, including economic, political and currency risks,' noted CitigroupSmith Barney in a report yesterday.</p><p>Other companies cited for similar exposure were Parkway, OCBC Bank, United Overseas Bank, DBS Bank and SingTel. 0CBC ended the session down 5 cents at 6.20 while UOB fell 20 cents to $14.10. SIA, whose fuel bill will rise with surging energy costs, slipped 10 cents to $11.70. Shipping giant NOL declined 10 cents to $3.16.</p><p>On the small caps front, Bio-Treat continued to hog the limelight on the volumes list amid news that global fund Capital Group had accumulated enough shares in the company to emerge as a substantial shareholder. The stock closed 1.5 cents higher at 98.5 cents. GES, another stock which Capital Group has bought into, rose half a cent to 86 cents.</p><p>Going forward, market insiders believe the market will remain hostage to the gyrations in oil prices.</p><p>'In the near term, besides oil prices, there are few key macro-economic drivers in Singapore, and we expect investors' interest to focus on corporate earnings,' OCBC Investment Research noted yesterday. 'With record higher energy prices, companies with high dependence on huge manufacturing facilities or oil-based raw materials needs are likely to be avoided for potential contraction in operating margins.'</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4HV2-69B0-0002-M3J1-00000-00<published>2005-12-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SINGAPORE COMPANIES</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>S'pore investors still net US-share buyers;<br/>But Q3 volume falls on hurricane Katrina's impact on oil prices</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Chuang Peck Ming</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SINGAPORE investors continued to pick up more shares than they dumped on Wall Street in the July-September quarter. But they cut their overall trade in US stocks sharply as hurricane Katrina struck New Orleans to send oil prices shooting past US$70 per barrel.</p><p nitf:lede="true">They bought US$4.5 billion and sold US $4 billion of US equities in the third quarter, when the US economic picture and corporate results were also rather mixed, according to the latest data released by the United States Treasury.</p><p nitf:lede="true">After bouncing back to increase their dealings to US$13.4 billion in Q2, Singapore investors backed off in Q3 by trading just US$8.5 billion in the US stock market - down 36.4 per cent from the preceding quarter.</p><p>In the April-June quarter, they mopped up US $7.6 billion and sold US$5.9 billion of US stocks, despite a spike in oil prices and the disappointing showing of the US economy.</p><p>Asian investors as a whole also reduced their trading in the US stock market in Q3, but by less than one per cent to US$64.1 billion.</p><p>The Japanese - the biggest Asian investors on Wall Street - continued to expand their presence by upping transactions to US$26.9 billion, from US$25.6 billion in Q2.</p><p>Hong Kong investors also were more active in Q3, boosting their trade from US$5.1 billion in Q2 to US$7.4 billion. And the Taiwanese increased their transactions from US$3.9 billion to US$4.2 billion.</p><p>Globally, investors bought and sold US$2.2 trillion of US stocks in Q3, about the same as in Q2, while the Europeans trimmed their trade from US$920.2 billion to US$904.6 billion.</p><p>During the quarter, the Dow Jones index gained 3.6 per cent in July, dipped 1.4 per cent in August and rose 0.8 per cent in September. The Nasdaq rose 6.2 per cent in July, fell 2 per cent the following month and stayed flat in September.</p><p>Wall Street has seen Singapore investors wind down their transactions for some time. And the lower trade in Q3 marked a resumption of a long-term exit from the US stock market as these investors shift their attention to bourses closer home, where the rise of China and India means more attractive returns.</p><p>Compared with the same period last year, Singapore investors' trade in US stocks in the first nine months of 2005 was 39.4 per cent down at US$23.1 billion, according to US Treasury data. But Singapore remained the second-biggest Asian investor on Wall Street.</p><p>China, the world's fastest-growing economy, chalked up US$1.2 billion in US stock trading in Q3, down from US$1.3 billion in the previous quarter.</p><p>India, the other emerging Asian star, remains a minor player in US stocks, posting only US$0.2 billion of transactions in Q3, up from US$0.1 billion in Q2.</p><p>India seemed more keen on US Treasury bonds, boosting its trade sharply from US$894 million in Q2 to US$2.4 billion in Q3. China, whose currency was until recently pegged solely to the US dollar, increased its trade in T-bonds by 13.3 per cent quarter on quarter to US$94.1 billion. It remained a net buyer of bonds.</p><p>Hong Kong, whose currency remains pegged to the US dollar, continued to step up its dealings in T-bonds and its net holdings. Hong Kong's transactions in T-bonds jumped 44.1 per cent from Q2 to US$68.4 billion in Q3.</p><p>Singapore, though still a major Asian investor in T-bonds, continued to reduce its trade. It's bond transactions dropped 14.9 per cent to US$36.6 billion.</p><p>For the first nine months, Singapore's trade in T-bonds slipped 4.3 per cent year on year to US$114.7 billion.</p><p>The Japanese remain the biggest Asian traders in T-bonds but cut their transactions by 22.4 per cent from Q2 to US$252.4 billion in Q3. However, they were still net buyers.</p><p>The Europeans also cut their trade in T-bonds, to US$3.1 trillion in the quarter under review from US$3.4 trillion in Q2.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">BUSTMS-051219049</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:4HVW-PCW0-0058-X21X-00000-00<published>2005-12-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>World</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>New Orleans faces a bleak Christmas;<br/>In the fourth part of a series that revisits disaster zones of 2005 even as Singaporeans count down to the season's festive cheer, Straits Times US Correspondent Eugene Low returns to New Orleans to look at the city devastated by Hurricane Katrina in late August</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FOR Hurricane Katrina evacuee Mimi Murphy, 36, this will be an especially difficult Christmas.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The massive flooding caused by the storm left her home ruined. So the mother of two will be spending the holiday season in a temporary trailer with her young children.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But having spent the past few months staying with friends and at hotels, she is just happy to be back in New Orleans.</p><p>The trailer - provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency - has been placed in the front yard of her damaged house.</p><p>'It has been a trying time, but we are just happy to be home,' she said.</p><p>More than 100 days after Katrina struck New Orleans on Aug 29, thousands of families are still homeless.</p><p>Like Ms Murphy, some 40,000 people continue to live in trailers and other mobile homes.</p><p>Another 42,000 are staying in hotel rooms paid for by the government. However, they have been told that it will stop paying their bills after Jan 7.</p><p>Hurricane Katrina killed more than 1,300 people in Louisiana, Mississippi, Florida, Georgia and Alabama. The damage is expected to cost insurers at least US$34.4 billion (S$57.5 billion) in claims.</p><p>It will count as the costliest hurricane in US history but not, by a long shot, the most powerful.</p><p>On Wednesday, the National Hurricane Centre released a report that downgraded the storm's intensity at landfall in Louisiana from Category 4 to Category 3.</p><p>Estimates of Katrina's power are expected to play a central role in the on-going investigations into the failures that led to the catastrophic flooding of New Orleans. The winds in New Orleans, which lay to the west of the storm's centre, were probably even weaker, at Category 1 or 2 speeds, the report said.</p><p>Still, the storm breached New Orleans' system of protective levees, flooding up to 80 per cent of the city.</p><p>Once famous for its laid-back way of life, it is is struggling to recover. It was home to more than half a million people, but less than a quarter of those who left have returned.</p><p>Around 30 per cent of the city still has no power. In some of the poorest areas, the prospects for recovery remain uncertain.</p><p>City planners might decide not to rebuild some of these neighbourhoods, given the high costs involved in protecting them against future hurricanes.</p><p>On Wednesday, the US Senate approved US$29 billion in funds for rebuilding levees, schools and other structures in hard-hit Gulf Coast states.</p><p>The money, more than $10 billion above the Bush administration's request, was attached to an end-of-year defence spending Bill that the Senate approved.</p><p>While progress may not be as fast as many would like, there are some hopeful signs emerging from the historic French Quarter, one of New Orleans' main tourist attractions.</p><p>Flooding was less severe there, and the district is picking itself up gradually. A growing number of shops, restaurants and bars are re-opening, although the crowds remain thin.</p><p>The city has also resumed its historic street-car service, whose infrastructure was damaged by Katrina.</p><p>But efforts to rebuild the city still face serious challenges.</p><p>For one, businesses seeking to resume operations continue to face severe staff shortages.</p><p>'Help wanted' signs adorn the windows of almost every shop and restaurant in the French Quarter.</p><p>The well-known Cafe du Monde, which, for more than 100 years, has supplied fresh coffee and French pastries round-the-clock, has had to shorten its opening hours.</p><p>It re-opened two months ago, but the locals and tourists who once thronged the place have been slow to return.</p><p>'Business has not been so good, and I think it will take at least another six months before things go back to normal,' said waitress Dung Nyugen, 48.</p><p>New Orleans is in dire need of revenue from tourism, which has always been a crucial part of the city's budget.</p><p>Officials and residents are now debating whether the annual Mardi Gras celebration should go ahead as usual in February.</p><p>Like other evacuees who have returned to New Orleans, Ms Murphy is eager to help rebuild the city she loves.</p><p>She is happy to call New Orleans 'home'.</p><p>'We are a stubborn people, and we will do what it takes to help the city make a comeback,' she said.</p><p><email Nevertheless, Mr Low said: 'Despite 2004 being the costliest year on record in terms of insured losses, the downward pressure on reinsurance rates continued.'</p><p>And in the US, he said, oceanographic forecasters predict 'a whopping 21 tropical storms - double the norm - before the end of the hurricane season this year'.</p><p>Even so, said Mr Low, the unpredictability of the scale of natural catastrophes continues to confound experts. Risk analysis is vital, but the scope of what Mother Nature can do is simply too wide, he said.</p><p>'For simplicity, traditional statistical methods have assumed that the severity and frequency of future losses will be comparable to those in the past, with appropriate adjustments made for rising concentration in insured values.'</p><p>But, he asked, with the speed of economic change, can history be relied upon to analyse future risks? 'At a more specific level, there is no reliable model to estimate damage caused by flooding, which partly contributed to the difficulty and delay in arriving at firm estimates of insurance losses from Hurricane Katrina,' he said.</p><p>The role of insurers and reinsurers in mitigating the financial impact of natural disasters is 'so important, but often not recognised'.</p><p>'On the contrary, insurers and reinsurers often get the brunt of the blame if payouts are not made on time or when insurance coverage in the policy contracts is not clear. In a natural catastrophe, with substantial loss of lives and property, insurers are often pressured on compassionate grounds into making compensation even if they are not contractually obliged to do so.'</p><p>Clarity in insurance contracts will give insurers a greater handle on their liabilities. Mr Low cited the difficulties in Hurricane Katrina where victims are uncertain whether they can claim for damage by flooding and looting.</p><p>Many standard policies exclude coverage of flood damage, and 'it is uncertain whether insurers would agree to recognise claims arising from flood damage to avoid unwanted legal suits and the ensuing bad publicity'. If this happens, reinsurers will be forced to follow suit.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5PC1-MF71-JB7G-0546-00000-00U.S. accepts S'pore's offer of help2017-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisWNPWorldPg. 52U.S. accepts S'pore's offer of help

The United States has accepted Singapore's offer to render assistance for disaster relief efforts in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey.

In response to media queries, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman said last night that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong called American President Donald Trump to express his concern and sympathies over the loss of life and damage caused by the storm.

PM Lee offered Singapore's assistance in disaster relief efforts by deploying the Republic of Singapore Air Force's (RSAF) CH-47 Chinook helicopters from its Peace Prairie detachment in Grand Prairie, Texas.

Mr Trump thanked PM Lee and accepted his offer, said the spokesman.

The hurricane has killed at least 10 people, led to mass evacuations and paralysed Houston, the fourth most-populous American city.

In 2005, the RSAF deployed four CH-47 Chinook helicopters to Fort Polk, Louisiana to assist in disaster relief efforts following the deadly Hurricane Katrina, the costliest natural disaster to strike the US. The team carried out various missions ranging from relocating evacuees to transporting Zodiac boats to facilitate search and rescue efforts.

The MFA's spokesman also said both leaders also looked forward to their meeting in the White House this October.

It threatened to swamp the historic city of New Orleans and cost millions in damage to US insurers, oil companies, and casinos.</p><p nitf:lede="true">S'pore-India air pact a good start, but more work remains</p><p nitf:lede="true">LAST week, an agreement was inked for more flights between Singapore and the Indian cities of Kolkata, Bangalore and Hyderabad. The deal is more important in spirit than in substance, for the three critical points of Chennai, Mumbai and New Delhi which account for two thirds of the traffic between the two countries were left out, says our senior correspondent Ven Sreenivasan.</p><p>Olam earnings up 39% as all sectors improve</p><p>AGRICULTURAL commodity supplier Olam International - listed on the mainboard early this year - yesterday reported a 39 per cent jump in full-year profit to $67.03 million as revenue rose 29 per cent to $3.38 billion. 'We have had an exceptional year with broad based growth across all our business segments,' said managing director and chief executive Sunny Verghese.</p><p>Bio-Treat chalks up 30% net profit jump</p><p>BIO-TREAT Technology yesterday reported a 30 per cent jump in net profit to 327.6 million yuan (S$67.8 million) for the year ended June 30 - thanks largely to a 49 per cent increase in sales to 1.25 billion yuan. The company has proposed a scrip dividend scheme that offers shareholders the option to receive dividend in the form of new ordinary shares of HK$0.40 each, instead of cash.</p><p>Local petrol prices go up by nine cents a litre</p><p>THE spiking of oil prices above US$70 a barrel yesterday coincided with petrol pump prices here jumping another nine cents to almost $2 a litre. ExxonMobil said that it would adjust its pumps from 6pm yesterday, raising the price of 98 octane grade to $1.927 a litre.</p><p>Hurricane Katrina pushes oil prices past US$70</p><p>CRUDE oil futures surged past US$70 a barrel for the first time yesterday as Hurricane Katrina barrelled towards the heart of US oil and refinery operations in the Gulf of Mexico, shutting down an estimated one million barrels of refining capacity. Light, sweet crude for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange jumped as much as US$4.67 a barrel in Singapore to hit a high of US $70.80 before slipping to US$69.71 by afternoon in Europe.</p><p>AirAsia rebuts MAS 'protection' charge</p><p>AIRASIA of Malaysia has rebutted allegations that it was being protected and blew its trumpet at the expense of Malaysian Airline System (MAS). The skirmish reflects an intense, and often bitter, competition between MAS, long the undisputed voice of Malaysia's airline industry, and newcomer AirAsia for the affections of Kuala Lumpur.</p><p>China, India in talks on joint energy project</p><p>CHINA National Petroleum Corporation, China's biggest oil company, is in talks with ONGC, the Indian government-controlled energy group, to cooperate on 'a specific project' in an unnamed third country, the Financial Times reported yesterday. CNPC told the paper that the two companies had a 'good cooperative relationship' that was being strengthened by the recent improvement in bilateral political ties.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Thirty-eight RSAF personnel, comprising pilots, aircrew and technicians, are deployed in the mission.'</p><p>In a letter to President George Bush, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the Federal Emergency Management Agency, through the National Guard, has asked the Singapore Air Force's Chinook detachment at Grand Prairie, Texas, to lend a hand.</p><p>'America has always been generous in helping others in their time of need,' Mr Lee said in the letter. 'We in South-east Asia have experienced that, most recently during the tsunami relief operations. Singapore is happy to reciprocate in a small way by participating in your efforts to save lives and restore normality to your people.'</p><p>Responding to Singapore's help, US Ambassador to Singapore Franklin Lavin said: 'Americans will long remember this immediate help from the RSAF, which interrupted their training programme to assist American efforts.'</p><p>One of the worst natural disasters in US history, hurricane Katrina, which slammed into the Louisiana coast on Monday, pounded and flooded the city of New Orleans, causing massive destruction and claiming thousands of lives.</p><p>Mindef said Singapore's Chinooks - from the RSAF's Peace detachment at Grand Prairie - arrived at Fort Polk, Louisiana, on the afternoon of Sept 1 (local time).</p><p>The RSAF has worked with the Texas Army National Guard previously, including relief operations after hurricane Floyd in North Carolina in 1999, and fire-fighting and flood relief in Texas in 2000.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:59X7-XXC1-DYX4-02B8-00000-00Can Obama recover from Obamacare debacle?2013-11-26T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisEDITORIAL & OPINIONThe Bottom LineCan Obama recover from Obamacare debacle?leon hadarWashington Correspondent

IT has become the dominant line of the day among the chattering classes in Washington: The appalling rollout of President Barack Obama's healthcare law ("Obamacare") has raised questions about the competence of his administration in the same way that former President George W Bush's failed response to Hurricane Katrina had damaged the public's confidence in his leadership.

So should we use the "K" word when discussing the Obama administration? Or to put it in blunt terms: Is Obamacare Mr Obama's Katrina'

And since the Bush administration's botched response to Hurricane Katrina had the effect of undermining the rest of Mr Bush's agenda, will the Obamacare mess have the same disastrous impact on the rest of Mr Obama's term'

The defining image of Mr Bush during Katrina was of him watching the devastation in New Orleans from the Air Force plane, making him appear more like a detached observer than a hands-on president engaged in responding to it. Mr Obama's critics would argue that his defining image is of him promising the American people before the launch of Obamacare in 2009 that "No matter how we reform healthcare, we will keep this promise: if you like your doctor, you will be able to keep your doctor. Period."

In reality, and contrary to those early promises, millions of Americans were required to give up their healthcare insurance plans after Obamacare went into effect.

Mr Obama's supporters would argue that it's not fair to compare what was in essence a technical glitch on the Obamacare website (Healthcare.gov) with the Hurricane Katrina disaster where 1,833 Americans died and more than US$80 billion worth of property was destroyed with the recovery operations costing American taxpayers more than US$100 billion.

"There's a qualitative difference between people dying in New Orleans and people not able to get healthcare," said former Bush strategist and pollster Matthew Dowd on ABC's This Week news show on Sunday. "But from a political standpoint, it's eerily similar to President Bush in the fall of 2005"

Indeed, the American public's response to the launching of Obamacare seems to suggest that Mr Obama may be facing his Katrina moment. According to a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, Mr Obama's job approval hit a new low in October, while his personal approval rating turned negative for the first time during his presidency.

In a way, both presidents were already facing a lot of public criticism early in the first year of their respective second terms - in the case of Mr Bush, it was about the handling of the war in Iraq; in Mr Obama's case, it was regarding his management of the economy. In that context, Katrina and Obamacare can be seen as the last straw that broke the White House camel's back, making both men look totally ineffective and untrustworthy.

It's true that Mr Obama had experienced dramatic falls in public approval of his job performance in the past and was able to bounce back. But as the NBC News/Wall Street Journal pollsters noted, he was always able to maintain high approval ratings when it came to the perception of him as an honest public figure. But in the aftermath of the Obamacare mess, a majority of Americans say they don't believe that he is honest or trust him as a person.

That is clearly quite politically devastating from Mr Obama's perspective and raises doubts over whether he will be able to recover from this setback. It's not inconceivable that the administration's high-tech professionals will succeed in fixing the healthcare.gov website sooner rather than later, and that more Americans will sign up to Obamacare. But opinion polls continue to point out that about 60 per cent of Americans remain opposed to what is regarded as Mr Obama's signature legislation. And it's unlikely that these attitudes will change anytime soon.

But while the results of the post-Obamacare opinion polls have been a huge disappointment to the White House and the Democrats, the same polls also suggest that the Republican Party and, in particular, the members of its congressional contingency are even less popular than President Obama. According to the NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, more than 50 per cent of Americans share a negative view of the Republican Party, and more Americans mistrust Congress than they mistrust the White House.

So Mr Obama and his aides are praying, wishing and hoping that a major acceleration in the economic recovery will take place before next year's mid-term congressional elections and help change the public's perception of the president. But they also recall that in the mid-term elections that followed Katrina, the Republicans were badly beaten and haven't been able to recover from that electoral blow since then.

Bush expressing sorrow at the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina. His letter yesterday also said an RSAF helicopter detachment in Texas was being deployed to help in relief efforts:</p><p nitf:lede="true">Dear President Bush,</p><p nitf:lede="true">At the time of one of the worst natural disasters in America's history, the thoughts of Singaporeans and me are with you and the American people whose lives have been devastated by Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true">I watched in awe the scenes of the destruction wreaked on the Gulf Coast of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. I saw the beautiful, gracious Southern city of New Orleans, which I had visited as a student many years ago, now pounded and inundated by the storm and the floods. Your resolute leadership during this period will be more important than ever.</p><p>The Federal Emergency Management Agency, through the National Guard, has asked Singapore Air Force's Chinook detachment in Grand Prairie, Texas, to help in the relief efforts. Our air force will be deploying Chinooks to Fort Polk, Louisiana today. Our people will be working side by side with the men and women of the Texas National Guard on this mission.</p><p>America has always been generous in helping others in their time of need. We in South-east Asia have experienced that, most recently during the tsunami relief operations.</p><p>Singapore is happy to reciprocate in a small way, by participating in your efforts to save lives and restore normality to your people.</p><p>US 'will remember Singapore's help'</p><p>'Republic of Singapore Air Force personnel are saving lives in Louisiana and the Gulf Coast states today. All Americans are deeply grateful for the generous efforts of the three Singaporean Chinook helicopter teams assisting in the disaster relief operations underway.</p><p>Last year with the Asian tsunami disaster, we all saw that rapid response was critical in saving lives. Americans will long remember this immediate help from the RSAF, which interrupted their training programme to assist American efforts.'</p><p>MR FRANKLIN LAVIN, US Ambassador to Singapore in a statement yesterday, on the RSAF's help in disaster relief efforts</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4J3P-S4C0-0058-X0DY-00000-00<published>2006-01-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>World</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>S'poreans give $190,000 aid to Katrina victims</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Eugene Low , US Correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WASHINGTON - SINGAPOREANS have donated S$190,400 to the American Red Cross in aid of victims of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The money was collected during a month-long appeal launched by the SingaporeRed Cross last September.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Professor Chan Heng Chee, Singapore's Ambassador to the United States, presented a cheque for the amount to the American Red Cross in Washington last Tuesday.</p><p>Red Cross officials here welcomed the donation, saying the money will go towards the overall relief and rehabilitation effort.</p><p>Hurricane Katrina struck the Gulf Coast in the southern United States on Aug 29 last year. It killed at least 1,400 people and caused an estimated US$75 billion (S $122 billion) in damage.</p><p>'The total cost of relief efforts is expected to be around US$2.1 billion,' said Mr David Meltzer, senior vice-president of the American Red Cross.</p><p>'The contributions we have received so far are slightly less than that amount.'</p><p>The bulk of the money - some US$1.6 billion - is needed to provide emergency financial aid so that hurricane victims can buy food and other essentials.</p><p>Another US$345 million will be spent on providing emergency food and shelter to the survivors.</p><p>Singaporeans who still wish to contribute to the relief effort can do so through the SingaporeRed Cross, said Mr Meltzer.</p><p>Besides giving money, Singapore also rendered physical aid during the emergency response.</p><p>A detachment of Singapore Armed Forces pilots, then training in the US, flew helicopter missions to airlift hurricane survivors to safety.</p><p>'The US has been generous to Asia in the past, so it is right that we should do something in return,' said Prof Chan.</p><p>She also hoped the recent saga on the National Kidney Foundation would not deter Singaporeans from donating to charities.</p><p>After the NKF scandal came to light last year, thousands of donors stopped giving.</p><p>'Singaporeans are known for their quiet generosity to many causes and I hope they will continue to do this,' she told The Straits Times. 'They should trust that the actions taken to improve the governance of charities will right what is wrong.'</p><p>Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made a similar appeal during his New Year's message. He called on Singaporeans to help keep charities accountable and also urged them to continue giving to worthy causes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H22-TM80-0002-M3KK-00000-00<published>2005-09-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SHIPPING TIMES; Strait Talk</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hurricane Katrina's mixed effects on global shipping</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>David Hughes</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE world usually notices mariners and the shipping industry only in times of crisis; wars or natural disasters. And so it has been with Katrina. The mariners of the US Coast Guard have certainly come to the public attention as they rescued thousands of survivors from flooded areas of the country's Gulf Coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true">America is of course learning a painful lesson in disaster response but it is also being reminded just how dependent it is on the shipping industry and imported oil.</p><p>By now, four large cruise ships should be acting as emergency shelters and medical aid centres for elderly and infirm Louisiana residents and at the same time demonstrating how the shipping industry has flexible resources that can be deployed quickly.</p><p>The US dependence on imported oil is, though the fact of life that is being rammed home most forcefully to the average American. 'I paid three bucks a gallon today for gas,' a New England-based acquaintance complained bitterly to me last week. He was less than consoled when I told him most people in the rest of the world would consider that a give-away price.</p><p>The reason for increase is simple. About 10 per cent of US petrol production comes through the Gulf Coast and the area's refineries were closed down by Katrina.</p><p>Already the rising fuel price is affecting shipping. Last week, the 13 member lines of the Transpacific Stabilisation Agreement announced that they will be raising fuel levies in the US on land transportation of container boxes from next month, to recover part of their costs from surging fuel prices.</p><p>While container shipping lines are having to claw back the cost of increased fuel, other owners experiencing a short term windfall as the US shortage sucks in stocks from Europe, sending the product tanker spot market through the roof. Very little clean product usually crosses the Atlantic but by the beginning of this week product tankers were commanding an impressive WorldScale 400, something like double pre-Katrina rates. The bonanza may not last long. US waters' ship-to-ship oil cargo transfer specialist SPT has given a fairly upbeat assessment of the situation. It says, 'For those areas that have been impacted by Katrina, such as the refineries in Louisiana and Mississippi, SPT is currently off-loading at alternative ports to be able to meet its customers' needs.</p><p>Most pipelines are operating now, the LOOP (Louisiana Offshore Oil Port) is operational and more refineries are getting back into operation. The reduced capacity in the oil import infrastructure will last for some time and will cause volumes of crude oil to be imported to be lower for some days or weeks, but crude vessels will also be employed as storage vessels. Overall utilisation will thus not be impacted to a great extent.'</p><p>On the other hand, dry bulk carrier owners may be less sanguine about the knock-on effects of Katrina. New Orleans is a major grain exporting port. US-produced wheat has been selling well and exports running at about 18 per cent above last year's levels. Much of that goes through Galveston, Texas, but a significant portion passes through New Orleans. Diverting more wheat to Galveston would exacerbate congestion there while use of the East Coast or the St Lawrence Seaway would push up costs.</p><p>The US also exports maize and soya beans which are grown in the southern states and some proportion of which may have been damaged by the hurricane. New Orleans is the main port for these crops. Few seem to expect the city's wharves to be operational, and the river navigable in less than a month. Moreover, much will depend on the ability of the massive barge transport system in the Mississippi and connected waterways to swing back into action quickly.</p><p>So the question for dry bulk carrier owners is whether the disruption to US grain exports will be severe enough to affect the market. Katrina is impacting on shipping in one other way. Informa was planning to hold this year's Terminal Operations Conference & Exhibition for the Americas (Americas TOC2005) at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, New Orleans at the end of November.</p><p>Understandably it has switched venue to Savannah, but is donating US$50 to the American Red Cross for every delegate place booked at TOC2005 Americas in support of the New Orleans cause.</p><p>Meanwhile, the news from the US Coast Guard is that the area's ports and waterways are gradually starting to recover.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4SHP-T980-TX7D-H0RB-00000-00Democracy and a tale of three disasters2008-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisDemocracy and a tale of three disastersMasood Mohajer

THE devastation the massive earthquake has wrought on the people of Sichuan province is unfathomable to us in Singapore. Nargis, the cyclone that wreaked havoc on the lives of some 2.5 million Myanmarese, is a news bite.

As much as we feel for the plight of the victims, we are not the ones burdened with the loss of a loved one or the destruction of our homes.

What is glaringly evident from these two calamities and Hurricane Katrina in 2005, that flooded and destroyed New Orleans in the United States, is the response of the governments of each of these nations to those specific events.

The failure of the Bush administration was broadcast for all to see and it became clear that as much as the US professes to be a democratic society, differing sets of rules apply to its citizens.

Despite claiming to have the world's greatest army, it could not see to the needs of its own people. So one must ask the question: Are the Americans better in their vision of democracy and a system of government they seek to stamp on the rest of the globe?

In so far as the response of their 'freely elected government' to the plight of the residents of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina is concerned, I would say no.

Cyclone Nargis has wrought untold damage and continues to wreak unimaginable suffering on the Myanmarese who are still waiting for basic help. The ruling junta's response has been shameful and the lack of any significant pressure by Asean on it is a blight on the association.

To sit back and simply say we cannot interfere in the internal affairs of another nation is unacceptable. Asean should step in to offer aid and assistance for the common good.

What the devastating earthquake in China has shown is that despite being branded as a government that does not offer its citizens the freedoms so dearly espoused in the US, the Chinese government has shown the world through its actions that it is connected with its citizens and that they can count on it.

It has wasted no time to mobilise its massive army to aid its citizens. Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has spent time on the ground with the people and feels their plight.

The Chinese army is leaving no stone unturned to help end the suffering in Sichuan.

Beijing has shown itself to be a worthy government of the people. To those in government, I say, the proof is in the pudding.

Bush in mid-September on the sidelines of the United Nations summit meeting in New York, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said in a statement on its website.</p><p>The abrupt cancellation of the trip came as relief efforts in the aftermath of Katrina came under heavy criticism.</p><p>Both presidents spoke by phone last night and agreed to postpone Mr Hu's visit, which had originally been scheduled to run from tomorrow to Thursday.</p><p>President Hu's visit to the US was supposed to be part of a longer 13-day trip that would include visits to Canada and Mexico.</p><p>Mr Hu was quoted as saying in the Chinese Foreign Ministry statement that China 'stood resolutely with the Americans' in the relief effort and believed that the US government would succeed in rebuilding the devastated region.</p><p>Mr Bush, in turn, thanked Mr Hu 'for the sympathies of the Chinese people on the hardships suffered by Americans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina', said the White House spokesman.</p><p>The US leader said he welcomed Mr Hu to visit again at a time convenient to both sides.</p><p>'Both leaders agreed unanimously to work towards a constructive bilateral relationship,' the Chinese Foreign Ministry statement said.</p><p>Analysts had hoped that the Chinese leader's trip would help ease recent bilateral tension arising from disputes over trade and China's military spending.</p><p>Beijing has also been increasingly concerned by the rising chorus of anti-Chinese comments being voiced in Washington, and sees Mr Hu's trip as an opportunity to address these fears.</p><p>It is unclear as yet what ramifications the postponement of the contentious visit - the first by Mr Hu as the Chinese head of state - might have on bilateral ties.</p><p>Neither side could agree on the status of the visit even after six months of talks, with Beijing claiming that it was a state visit and the White House denying it that status.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier 'With continuing economic growth, employment should register further gains in the near term.'</p><p>Higher oil prices have been fanned by exceptionally strong global economic growth, especially in the United States and China, Mr Lim said.</p><p>'The strong growth has also lifted demand for Singapore's exports,' he said. 'This has more than offset the drag on domestic activities arising from higher energy costs.'</p><p>The latest rise in oil prices reflects a huge supply disruption in the US, caused by Hurricane Katrina, Mr Lim noted. The disruption in US economic activities and higher oil prices are expected to shave up to one percentage point off US economic growth in the second half. And that will slow Singapore's exports at the same time as the higher oil prices hit its domestic demand.</p><p>But Mr Lim said the impact is likely to be transient. 'The US economic growth momentum should recover in early 2006,' he said.</p><p>Oil prices have fallen sharply since their all-time high of US$70.85 on Aug 30, after Katrina disrupted oil refineries in the southern US. New York's main contract, light sweet crude for delivery in October, was trading below US$64 a barrel in Asian trade yesterday, but analysts say prices could spike again ahead of the northern winter.</p><p>Mr Lim also noted that the impact of high oil prices on Singapore's inflation has so far been limited.</p><p>'Between December 2003 and July this year, the CPI rose 1.6 per cent, compared to an increase of 93 per cent in crude oil prices,' he said.</p><p>'While the cost of fuel and utilities rose 10.6 per cent over the period, prices of other consumer items showed much smaller increases or declined.'</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier At the same time, rising demand from countries such as China is also raising the price of oil.</p><p>This long-term increase, however, is accompanied by correspondingly rising demands in other sectors, which will stimulate Singapore's economy and compensate for high oil prices.</p><p>Some businesses may hold back, Mr Lim said, but others will still choose to expand to meet new demands.</p><p>Economic growth in the United States may fall as much as one percentage point below expectations for the quarter due to Hurricane Katrina, though it should recover by early 2006.</p><p>Singapore's economy, however, is on track for expected growth of 3.5 per cent to 4.5 per cent this year, he said.</p><p>Global oil futures have declined 8.9 per cent since touching a record US$70.85 a barrel on Aug 30, in the wake of Katrina. But prices are still 42 per cent higher than a year ago.</p><p>Non-Constituency MP Steve Chia asked in a separate question later whether the Government was collecting more revenue from its petrol tax, and if the tax will be reduced in light of higher oil prices.</p><p>Mr Lim said the petrol tax is levied on a fixed rate per litre: 'Petrol duty revenue depends on the volume rather than the price of petrol.'</p><p>He added later: 'We must not fall into the trap of adjusting tax rates every time there is a price change...Rather than insulate ourselves from global price changes, we must learn to adjust our consumption in accordance with these price changes'.</p><p>Nominated MPs Ivan Png and Geh Min also asked whether the government should do more to encourage the use of hybrid vehicles and alternative fuels here.</p><p>Mr Lim indicated that these will become more attractive to consumers as the technology becomes more mature.</p><p>In the meantime, he asked Singapore citizens to be nonetheless careful to conserve fuel.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
