urn:contentItem:4H1M-X2H0-0058-X4D6-00000-00<published>2005-09-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Asia - China</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Analysts upbeat on delay of Hu's US visit;<br/>It generates goodwill for the Chinese President, who shows concern for the plightof American hurricane victims</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Chua Chin Hon , China Bureau Chief</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BEIJING - THE abrupt postponement of Chinese President Hu Jintao's visit to the United States this week may not be the disappointment it seems on first sight, said analysts here.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Though both countries have a broad range of trade and strategic issues to address, US President George W. Bush is clearly too preoccupied with the fallout from Hurricane Katrina to give the visit his full attention.</p><p nitf:lede="true">With thousands dead and many more left homeless by the hurricane, it would have also seemed inappropriate for the White House to roll out the red-carpet welcome for Mr Hu.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By showing that he understood Washington's predicament at a time of crisis, combined with Beijing's healthy donation for disaster relief, Mr Hu could gain considerable goodwill when the visit gets on track again, analysts said.</p><p>'I think President Bush is preoccupied with a lot of things right now, and China is not on his front-burner at the moment,' said Professor Richard Baum, a veteran China watcher with the University of California.</p><p>'I think both sides can afford to wait.'</p><p>Both the White House and Beijing announced late on Saturday that Mr Hu's visit to the US - his first as the Chinese head of state - would be postponed indefinitely due to Hurricane Katrina. It had been scheduled to run from today till Thursday.</p><p>In a telephone conversation with Mr Bush, Mr Hu said China 'stood resolutely with the Americans' in the relief effort.</p><p>The US leader, in turn, thanked Mr Hu 'for the sympathies of the Chinese people on the hardships suffered by Americans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina'.</p><p>China also announced on Saturday that it was donating emergency supplies and US$5 million (S$8.4 million) in disaster relief to the US.</p><p>'The postponement of the visit will boost, not weaken, bilateral ties,' argued Professor Shen Dingli, deputy director of Fudan University's Centre for American Studies.</p><p>'China has shown respect, concern and understanding for America's predicament, and there will be more goodwill shown in a future visit.'</p><p>Prior to the postponement, analysts had seen Mr Hu's visit as coming at a critical juncture for Sino-US ties, which has been dominated by an increasing number of disputes over trade, currency issues and China's military spending.</p><p>There had been hope that his trip will help cool bilateral tension on these fronts, though early signs were that it would have been a contentious visit had it gone ahead as planned.</p><p>For one, neither side could agree on the status of the visit.</p><p>Beijing insists that it is a state visit, while the White House says it is not.</p><p>The significance is not just a semantic one for Beijing, which is sensitive to diplomatic protocol. Some analysts feared that the unintended snub could have affected the success of the visit.</p><p>Said Prof Baum: 'There has been a lot of confusion on both sides on the protocol involved and I think if the meeting had been held as scheduled, it might have created even worse misunderstandings and feelings of being slighted on protocol mistakes.'</p><p>Mr Hu's visit to the US was supposed to be part of a longer 13-day trip that would include visits to Canada and Mexico. For now, there is no indication as to how the rest of his visit would be affected, or when the US visit would be rescheduled again.</p><p>However, both presidents have agreed to meet in mid-September on the sidelines of the United Nations summit in New York, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said.</p><p>In that meeting, Mr Hu's priority would still be on stressing China's commitment to a policy of 'peaceful development', said Professor Jin Canrong of People's University.</p><p>He added: 'The US has strong strategic suspicions of China, so the main task would be to lower this suspicion. Only after that would specific issues be addressed.'</p><p><email opportunities open up</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Goh Eng Yeow</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE first trading day of September kicked off with the market in a sunny mood.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Traders saw opportunities for local firms in the wake of the devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina in the Gulf of Mexico.</p><p nitf:lede="true">And for mobile phone repairer Accord Customer Care Solutions (ACCS), investors put aside concerns over its accounts and ongoing criminal investigations, focusing instead on the possibility of a white knight riding to its rescue.</p><p>The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 20.11 points to 2,295.54 yesterday, after falling in two of the three previous sessions.</p><p>Although September is traditionally a quiet period for the market, overall volume yesterday soared to 946.63 million shares worth $996.07 million.</p><p>The broad market saw 330 gainers outpace 153 losers.</p><p>The day began with a morning call by analysts to focus on rebuilding efforts in the Gulf, after Wall Street was buoyed by the United States' decision to tap into its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which eased supply concerns.</p><p>Kim Eng's online research arm, Kelive, said: 'Looking at the destruction trail left behind by Hurricane Katrina, contrarians are likely to see this as an opportunity to re-enter the markets.</p><p>'Damaged oil rigs at the Gulf could mean more contracts for firms such as rig-builders Keppel and SembCorp.'</p><p>Keppel rose 60 cents to $12.20 on volume of 6.9 million shares; SembCorp Marine (SembMarine) was up 15 cents at $2.95 on volume of 11.5 million shares.</p><p>However, OCBC Securities noted any supply problem that surfaces while the damage created by Katrina is being repaired would lie more with a 'major bottleneck' in actual refining capacity.</p><p>Reflecting these concerns, the stocks of Singapore Petroleum Co - the Republic's only refiner - shot up 30 cents to a record high of $5.75 on volume of 4.1 million shares.</p><p>Still, the day's biggest story was ACCS' 47.6 per cent rise to 15.5 cents on volume of 64.8 million shares. It was the most actively traded stock.</p><p>The jump came after ACCS disclosed it had at least three suitors.</p><p>However, NetResearch noted that the rise might be merely a 'dead-cat bounce', with traders 'dismissing the short-term excitement as premature'.</p><p>It was also a blue skies day for new listings. Stocks of steel distributor Asia Enterprise ended at 29.5 cents, or 2.5 cents above the offer price.</p><p><email urn:contentItem:5PC1-X361-JCF2-835T-00000-00Trump accepts PM's offer of copters for relief effort2017-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisTOP OF THE NEWSTrump accepts PM's offer of copters for relief effort

United States President Donald Trump has accepted Singapore's offer of its Chinook helicopters based in Texas to assist in disaster relief operations in the wake of Hurricane Harvey.

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made the offer in a call to Mr Trump yesterday, during which both leaders said they look forward to meeting in the White House in October.

PM Lee had called Mr Trump to express his concern and sympathies over the loss of life and damage in Texas and Louisiana.

He said Singapore was ready to assist in ongoing relief efforts by deploying the Republic of Singapore Air Force's CH-47 Chinook helicopters from its Peace Prairie detachment in Grand Prairie, Texas, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman said.

President Trump thanked PM Lee and accepted his offer of help.

The RSAF detachment in Grand Prairie was set up in 1995 to train Chinook crewmen and maintenance personnel.

Four of its helicopters and 41 personnel had assisted in a relief mission for Hurricane Katrina in Louisiana in September 2005, during which they worked alongside the Texas Army National Guard.

Yesterday, Mr Trump took PM Lee's call while on board Air Force One on his way to Texas for an update on the flooding crisis.

Both leaders also discussed North Korea's "continued and deliberate provocations, including the latest ballistic missile launch", with the missile flying over Japan.

PM Lee said Singapore was deeply concerned and had issued a statement condemning this reckless action.

"We strongly urge North Korea to cease all provocations immediately, and reiterate our longstanding call for North Korea to abide by its international obligations and commitments," he added in a Facebook post.

His upcoming meeting with Mr Trump comes after they met at the Group of 20 Leaders' Summit in Hamburg, Germany, last month. At that meeting, Mr Trump said he looked forward to receiving PM Lee in Washington later this year.

urn:contentItem:4H6B-78V0-0058-X1K5-00000-00<published>2005-09-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Singapore</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Pump prices fall for first time in 3 months;<br/>Further drop likely in coming weeks with less demand during fasting month in Indonesia</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Christopher Tan , SENIOR CORRESPONDENT</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">AFTER successive increases of between six and nine cents, petrol prices yesterday fell by two to three cents a litre - the first price drop since June.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But the good news is that prices are expected to head farther south in coming weeks because of an expected drop in regional demand.</p><p nitf:lede="true">At noon yesterday, Shell started the ball rolling by cutting rates of its 92, 95 and 98-octane petrols by three cents, to $1.782, $1.814 and $1.897 per litre respectively. Its V-Power premium grade fell by two cents to $1.97 a litre, and its diesel was down three cents to $1.19.</p><p>Within 1 1/2 hours, ExxonMobil, Caltex and Singapore Petroleum Company had matched Shell's adjustment. SPC was the last to move, at 1.30pm.</p><p>Energy consultant Ong Eng Tong said the price cut followed petrol wholesale prices falling by about US $2 (S$3.39) a barrel since the Hurricane Katrina-induced peak three weeks ago.</p><p>Yesterday, wholesale 92-octane petrol closed below US$73 a barrel, down from around US$77. The peak price was posted when crude oil - the raw material for petrol - crossed US$70 at the end of last month. The price rose on fears that Hurricane Katrina would cripple US oil production in the Gulf of Mexico.</p><p>With a barrel containing about 159 litres, a US$1 movement in the wholesale barrel rate translates to a change of over two cents a litre in retail prices here.</p><p>Even with yesterday's cut, petrol now costs 40 to 45 per cent more than it did three years ago. Should prices not fall more substantially, now that crude oil has fallen from US$70 to around US$63 a barrel?</p><p>Mr Ong said: 'The truth of it is that nobody is going to sell petrol at less than what they can sell it at wholesale.'</p><p>And regional demand, from big consumers like Indonesia and China, has kept wholesale rates buoyant. But that is set to change.</p><p>'With the Muslim fasting month starting on Oct 5, there will be less demand from Indonesia. The Indonesians have already stockpiled on petrol for the Puasa month,' he explained.</p><p>'Historically, prices fall by about 10 per cent during this period.'</p><p>That would mean pump prices here could fall by at least seven cents in the coming weeks.</p><p>Mr Seah Seng Choon, executive director of Consumers Association of Singapore, said of yesterday's reduction: 'It is a move in the right direction, and we expect oil companies to lower more should wholesale prices continue to fall.'</p><p><email urn:contentItem:4H1V-VCY0-0002-M3HB-00000-00<published>2005-09-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>TOP STORIES</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Three-minute digest</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Indonesian plane crashes in Medan, killing 130</p><p nitf:lede="true">A DOMESTIC airliner crashed in a busy residential area in Medan, Indonesia's third biggest city just after take-off yesterday, killing about 100 people aboard and 30 bystanders on the ground. Mandala Airlines officials said 13 passengers sitting in the tail section of the Boeing 737-200 survived the crash.</p><p nitf:lede="true">FairPrice should not be listed: outgoing chairman</p><p nitf:lede="true">OUTGOING NTUC FairPrice chairman S Chandra Das hopes that the supermarket chain will remain a co-operative and never be listed, so that it may continue performing its social mission of keeping prices of essential goods affordable.</p><p>Damaged STE ops in US undergoing recovery work</p><p>HURRICANE Katrina has caused some damage to the US Gulf Coast operations of Singapore Technologies Engineering but recovery work is already underway. ST Mobile Aerospace Engineering, located in Mobile, Alabama, had only minor damage and the facility has resumed operations.</p><p>SembCorp Marine shares surge on order hopes</p><p>SHARES of SembCorp Marine Ltd gained 1.7 per cent on expectations the company may win more orders as oil prices rise, analysts said. The stock, which surged to an intraday record price of $3.10, rose 5 cents to close at $3.02.</p><p>OCBC names new audit, risk mgt chiefs</p><p>OCBC Bank is undergoing changes at its top positions. Chong Meng is retiring as head of group audit after five years with the bank. Taking his place from Oct 1 is Lai Teck Poh, 61, currently OCBC's head of group risk management.</p><p>Hungry Ghosts don't scare off property auction sales</p><p>NEVER mind the hungry ghosts and taboos - Singaporeans are shedding their inhibitions about buying and selling property during the lunar Seventh Month, according to Colliers International. The number of properties put up for auction during the traditionally 'inauspicious' period has increased in recent years, it says.</p><p>Just straight A's won't get you these plum jobs</p><p>TALENT cultivation is the main reason big firms here want young, enthusiastic, mobile recruits. And diversity seems to be a common theme in their search for potential high-flyers. CapitaLand, for example, is looking for people 'with diverse backgrounds and interests' who are excited by the prospect of working overseas.</p><p>Oil prices slide on emergency supplies deal</p><p>OIL prices fell heavily in London yesterday after industrial powers had agreed to release emergency supplies of crude to counter severe disruption by Hurricane Katrina of oil production in the Gulf of Mexico. The price of Brent North Sea crude for October delivery fell by US$1.38 to US$64.68 per barrel.</p><p>Bursa moves to expand range of remisiers</p><p>BURSA Malaysia is in talks with the Securities Commission on tweaking the licences of remisiers so that they can handle more financial products. Malaysian Business Times quoted Bursa CEO as saying that with the adjustment, some 6,000 traders would be able to provide services for products such as futures and not just equities.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5PG1-GNX1-DYX4-048N-00000-00US envoy thanks Singapore for help after warship collision2017-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisTOP OF THE NEWSUS envoy thanks Singapore for help after warship collisionAnnabeth Leow

Singapore's response was "overwhelmingly generous and kind" after last month's deadly warship collision, the top United States diplomat here has said.

In her first public remarks since the incident involving the USS John S. McCain, charge d'affaires Stephanie Syptak-Ramnath yesterday thanked the Government and Singaporeans for their "generous support during that difficult moment".

She cited the "immediate and continuous air, personnel and maritime support" and the offers of aid from regular Singaporeans.

Ten US sailors were killed and five others injured in an early- morning collision with an oil tanker in Singapore waters off Pedra Branca on Aug 21.

"It is often said that our greatest challenges reveal our closest friends, and that is what we were reminded (of) on Aug 21 and the days that followed," said Ms Syptak-Ramnath.

The former US naval officer was speaking at a business event organised by the American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore.

She added: "That same concerned and uncalculating friendship was on display in more recent days, as Singapore became one of the first foreign governments to assist in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey in Texas."

The Republic of Singapore Air Force deployed four helicopters and assisted in disaster relief operations in the battered south- western American state earlier this month.

That was a reminder of its military aid after Hurricane Katrina in 2005, which Ms Syptak-Ramnath called "another sign of the longstanding partnership that exists between our two countries".

Minister for Trade and Industry (Trade) Lim Hng Kiang, who was also at the business event at the Four Seasons Singapore hotel, thanked the charge d'affaires for her "kind remarks". He added: "It shows the wide-ranging relations between the US and Singapore."

Ms Syptak-Ramnath has been heading her embassy in Singapore since Mr Kirk Wagar left his post as ambassador at the start of US President Donald Trump's administration.

KepCorp closed 20 cents up at $12.80 after touching an intra-day high of $12.90. There was also interest in Sesdaq-listed AusGroup, a Perth-based oil platform fabricator, which closed five cents higher at 34 cents.</p><p>Asked when repair deals could materialise, a KepCorp spokeswoman told BT: 'Some drilling contractors have contacted us. There have been several enquiries for repairs to damaged rigs. But it will take a while for contractors to assess the full extent of the damage, especially when it is substantial and involves insurance issues.'</p><p>Unless rig replacement is involved, KepCorp intends to handle work through its Keppel Amfels yard in Brownsville, Texas, which is next door to Mexico. The yard itself is 'out of the band' of the approaching Rita, the spokeswoman said.</p><p>A SembMarine spokeswoman confirmed yesterday that it too has received enquiries from storm-hit drilling contractors. And in a timely move, SembMarine said in a statement that it is in the process of acquiring Sabine Shipyard at Sabine Pass, on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico at the Texas-Louisiana border.</p><p>SembMarine said its plan to acquire the yard - which is equipped to build, repair and refurbish drilling rigs - is in line with its strategy of establishing a presence in the Gulf of Mexico to service the offshore exploration and production industry.</p><p>Crude oil and gasoline prices rose in Asian trade yesterday as Hurricane Rita headed towards Texas, where it is tipped to make land between Galveston and Corpus Christi and threaten the huge refining hub in the Houston area.</p><p>Crude oil jumped to almost US$68 a barrel, while gasoline futures hit US$2.15 a gallon. The market is concerned that the worldwide refining crunch could worsen. 'The Houston area is ground zero of the refining industry,' Bloomberg quoted Rick Mueller, an analyst with Energy Security Analysis, as saying.</p><p>Texas is home to 26 refineries, with 18 located near the Gulf of Mexico coast. They have a combined capacity of 4 million barrels a day - almost a quarter of US refining capacity.</p><p>Ahead of Rita, refiners including Marathon Oil, Valero Energy and BP have shut or scaled down their Texas refineries. And thousands of workers have been evacuated from offshore drilling rigs and production platforms as a safety precaution.</p><p>Four refineries in Louisiana and Mississippi, representing 5 per cent of US capacity, remain shut because of the damage caused by Hurricane Katrina last month.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata They made the pledge during a meeting hosted by the MAS and the IMF over the weekend.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A-Sonic, AirOcean scrap China budget airline plan</p><p nitf:lede="true">TWO Singapore-listed aviation players - A-Sonic Aerospace and AirOcean Group - and two Chinese parties have shelved their plan to set up a budget airline in China as they did not secure a key licence in time.</p><p>Time to rethink CPF curbs on foreign stocks?</p><p>IT is ironic that investors can use their retirement savings held in the Central Provident Fund to buy into financially troubled and currently unprofitable companies like L&M but are barred from buying into profitable top performers like Noble Group. Senior BT correspondent R Sivanithy argues that it is time to re-look at the Singapore-incorporated-only restriction on CPF funds.</p><p>ACU loans surge 13.6%, domestic lending slows</p><p>FOREIGN currency loans in July rose to almost US $100 billion as Singapore's external wing expands, while domestic lending slowed to 2 per cent with people remaining careful about taking on debt, according to latest data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.</p><p>Hurricane Katrina may check interest rate hikes</p><p>HURRICANE Katrina may have caused great devastation in the southern US but some strategists believe the catastrophe may give investors something they have wanted all year - a pause in interest rate hikes. They argue that the prospect of slower, post-Katrina growth is what Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan has been looking for as a reason to pause in its more than year-long policy of raising short-term rates to keep inflation under control.</p><p>Time is not on the side of Proton</p><p>MALAYSIA'S national carmaker Proton, which recently reported a plunge in its first-quarter profit, cannot afford to remain solo as foreign competition heats up, argues our KL correspondent S Jayasankaran. Despite its bleak financial prospect, Proton has resisted overtures from German carmaker Volkswagen and others. The longer Proton vacillates, the less Volkswagen, or any other global automaker, may be interested to help steer Proton in the new auto landscape.</p><p>Tokyo targets seven key industries for promotion</p><p>INDUSTRIAL policy, which has been out of favour in Japan for several decades, is coming back into fashion with the decision by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry to publish a plan targeting seven key industries for official promotion efforts. The seven focal industries are digital electronics, robotics, fuel cell development, environment and energy devices and services, health and welfare devices and services, business support services and 'content' business.</p><p>Soaring oil prices won't ground Asian travellers</p><p>SOARING oil prices are unlikely to ground Asian travellers ahead of the year-end holiday season but airlines could see profits eroded by escalating jet fuel bills, analysts say. Between now and 2008, Iata estimates international passenger volumes in the region will expand 8.3 per cent annually.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:802M-0XB1-2R99-300H-00000-00Uncertain future beckons2010-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisUncertain future beckons

MR NGUYEN TAO, 62Vietnamese owner of the China Sea restaurant

Buras (Louisiana) - It was love at first sight.

When Mr Nguyen Tao first set foot in this small oil-and-fishing town, he knew right away that he had found a new home.

'I thought I had found the promised land,' said the 62-year-old who, as a political refugee, fled Vietnam for the United States in 1984.

'The Mississippi River Delta here looks like the Mekong River delta where I grew up. I found everything here so familiar.'

He moved to Buras in 1991 with his wife and daughter, and set up the China Sea restaurant that year.

But they lost everything in 2005 when Hurricane Katrina struck, losing more than US $400,000 (S $546,000) in that disaster.

He worked in Dallas and New Orleans for the next four years, but could not forget Buras.

'My heart told me to come back, not my mind,' said Mr Tao, who began rebuilding China Sea last year. The restaurant reopened for business in March this year to much fanfare. A month later, however, his business was badly hit after an oil rig 65km off the Gulf Coast exploded and sank while working on an undersea well belonging to BP.

He even lost three of his employees to BP's cleanup operation, which offered workers US $120 a day in wages. Mr Tao could offer only the minimum wage rate of US $7.25 an hour.

The soft-spoken Vietnamese immigrant said he does not know what he will do next.

But in a recent letter that he wrote to BP, Mr Tao wrote: 'My future is now in your hands. Please take good care of it.'

Forced to rely on handouts

MS TA TAPONPANH, 51Laotian owner of Chanta Seafood

Bayou La Batre (Alabama) - Since moving to the United States from Laos in 1980 as a refugee, Ms Ta Taponpanh has prided herself on being a self-made woman who relied on her own hard work instead of handouts.

But the sharp and sudden impact of the BP oil spill not only led to the closure of her crabmeat processing plant, it also forced her to accept government-issued food stamps for the first time.

'Right now, I'm getting by with less than US $1,000 (S $1,360) a month,' said the 51-year-old, who previously drew a US $2,500 weekly salary at her own business, Chanta Seafood. 'I'm cutting back on almost everything. I don't shop, I don't go out, and I can't travel.'

So far, she has received only US $7,500 in compensation from BP. But her monthly bills for utilities, sewerage and rent have already come to US $13,000.

And with the supply of crabs falling by more than 10 times since the waters in the Gulf were closed in response to the oil spill, Ms Taponpanh said she has had no choice but to let her 35 workers go.

Given the uncertainties surrounding the Gulf seafood industry, would she wind up her business and move on?

'No. If I'm here, at least I can help my workers translate so that they can make their claims against BP,' said the entrepreneur, who took English classes in the 1980s.

For now, she is uncertain about how she will rebuild her business. But it won't be her first attempt at such a task.

Chanta Seafood was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina in August 2005, about a year after it was first launched. It took her and her husband nearly two years to secure new loans and to rebuild their premises before the plant was reopened again with 15 of her former employees.

Recovering from the fallout of the oil spill might take longer, but she said: 'I'm not going to leave. Seafood is my life and it is the only thing I know how to do.'

urn:contentItem:4JYD-56G0-TX7D-H2WB-00000-00Economies shrug off effects of $70US oil2006-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:19:00ZLexisNexisMONEYEconomies shrug off effects of $70US oilBut concerns remain about crude price hitting $100US and moreErica Tay

LAST year, it was Hurricane Katrina. This year, Iran's alleged nuclear ambitions.

In the last two years, global events have catapulted the price of crude oil to fresh highs time and again.

Last week, Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew told reporters here that the price of oil 'will go up be yond $100US to $150US' a barrel, in the event of an energy crisis over Iran.

'There will be a world recession, we are all in trouble,' he said.

So far, the world economy has held up exceedingly well in the face of the rising price of a commodity so fundamental to economic activity.

The question is, if and when oil prices hit $100US a barrel, will economic resilience continue?

Contrary to previous dire predictions, major economies did not slump into recession when oil prices hit $70US a barrel last August when Hurricane Katrina hit the United States. Nor were economies crippled when oil prices reached $75US last month, due to geopolitical tensions in oil-rich Iran.

In fact, growth in the economies of the US, Japan and Europe, along with Asia, has been healthy and the widely feared spectre of high inflation did not materialise. While pump prices spiked following these episodes, inflation levels in most countries remained surprisingly mild.

'Generally, we've been pretty fortunate that oil hasn't had a big impact on core inflation rates and growth over the last few years,' said Mr David Carbon, DBS' head of economic and currency research.

Given that crude oil products go into everything from plastics to petrol to cosmetics, pricier crude means raw materials cost more to businesses, putting a squeeze on profit margins.

An important 'shock absorber' has been the spread of global trade and the rise of China as the 'factory of the world'.

Globalisation has ensured that low labour costs in China are translated into cheap finished goods exported to the rest of the world.

Ms Selena Ling, the head of treasury research and strategy at OCBC Bank, said: 'Downward pricing pressures from manufactured goods such as electronics, especially those from China, have helped offset some of the commodity price inflation.'

Another countering factor, she noted, was that oil prices were pushed up not by any actual shortage in supply, but rather by rising demand from fast-growing economies.

Still, it does not stop concerns about oil hitting $100US a barrel. Quantum Fund co-founder Jim Rogers even predicted prices would reach $150US within a decade, as there has been no major oil discovery in 35 years.

A possible trigger of new highs would be, once again, the US hurricane season.

United Overseas Bank economist Thomas Lam said: 'I suspect that in the coming months, from June to November, when the hurricane season gets under way, there will be another source of upside risk.'

However, he believes that when oil stays above $80US a barrel, consumers will start to shy away from oil, bringing prices down again. 'Over the longer term, consumers' response becomes more obvious. People start to switch to alternative fuels, or drive less, or take public transport,' said Mr Lam.

'It's not like they expect business to fall.' After ramping up production in the third quarter and early in Q4 to meet holiday season demand, activity is bound to cool off in the months that follow, he said.</p><p>Sentiment may also have been hit by the timing of the poll, which was taken just after Hurricane Katrina hit the southern US, disrupting oil supplies and and pushing up prices, Mr Tang said.</p><p>Song Seng Wun of CIMB-GK said the slight weakening in business sentiment could also reflect uncertainty caused by external factors - a volatile equity market, the rise of global inflation and interest rates. 'The slightly less bullish sentiment is not entirely a surprise,' he said.</p><p>In the key electronics sector, a net weighted balance of 30 per cent of the manufacturers polled said they expect better business in the next six months.</p><p>'This optimistic outlook is led by the semiconductor and computer peripheral segments, which expect increased orders and exports in the last quarter of the year,' said EDB, which received responses from 94 per cent of 405 manufacturers polled.</p><p>Those in the data storage segment are less sanguine. They continue to phase out low-end computer disk drives. And manufacturers of information and communication devices and consumer electronics anticipate lower output after a cyclical peak in the third quarter.</p><p>Sentiment is still running high in the transport engineering cluster, with the marine and offshore segment most bullish - thanks to secured contracts for ship-building and ship conversion.</p><p>Manufacturers in this segment also expect more orders for oil rigs and oilfield equipment to meet increased activity and to replace rigs damaged by Hurricane Katrina.</p><p>The biomedicals sector, dominated by pharmaceuticals, is likely to remain the same for the next six months. But pharmaceuticals manufacturers said they see higher output in Q4 than in Q3.</p><p>In the services sector, real estate developers are the most upbeat about prospects in the next six months, with a net balance of 67 per cent expecting favourable conditions.</p><p>Department stores and retailers of wearing apparel and furniture and furnishing are especially looking forward to more business during the year-end festive season, according to DOS.</p><p>'Similarly, in the catering trade industry, restaurant and food caterers expect brisk business in the coming months,' it said.</p><p>In the wholesale trade, dealers in electronic components, telecommunications equipment and cosmetics and toiletries are among those bullish about the business outlook.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H58-D4J0-0002-M48C-00000-00<published>2005-09-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>VIEWS AND OPINIONS; Editorial</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>After Katrina, the Fed sees inflation</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE force of nature was not enough to stay the hand of the US Federal Reserve from raising interest rates further on Tuesday. Notwithstanding the devastating impact of Hurricane Katrina, the Fed boosted interest rates to the highest level in four years.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The key short-term interest rate was raised by one-quarter percentage point to 3.75 per cent - the 11th increase since the Fed began its tightening cycle in June 2004. In response, commercial banks began raising their prime lending rates as well, pushing borrowing costs to their highest since 2001.</p><p>Some had earlier thought Hurricane Katrina might bring a pause to the rate-hike regime. But the Fed made it clear that it still regarded inflation as the main threat. The risk that high energy prices could touch off broader inflation was considered greater than the threat of an economic slowdown. The Fed also left open the possibility of further rate increases, depending on economic conditions.</p><p>The tone of the Fed's statement was largely expected, but the question remains how long the current cycle of rate hikes will last. To some, what was notable at the last meeting was the dissent by governor Mark Olson, who voted for a pause in the rate increases. That he registered his disagreement in this way was unusual, given that dissents have occurred in only five of the past 46 Fed meetings since 2000, and could suggest more caution on the part of policy makers on raising interest rates further.</p><p>Also, not everyone agrees with the Fed's assessment of the US economy. The Fed said that before Katrina struck, the economy was moving ahead at a 'good pace'. But economists pointed out that pre-hurricane data had actually been poor. The figures included the sharp fall in August retail sales, production, small rise in payrolls, and weaker-than-expected housing starts. Economic activity is expected to moderate towards the end of this year, with weaker growth prospects seen in 2006. Going by such readings, interest rates should start falling going into 2006.</p><p>Ironically, the hurricane factor may postpone such a U-turn in monetary policy. The short-term impact of Katrina is, without doubt, dampening. Katrina is estimated to reduce US economic growth in the second half of this year by as much as one percentage point as high energy prices crimp consumer and business spending. Hiring is expected to slow, with a reduction of 400,000 jobs over the next four months. And Hurricane Rita, now blowing, could develop into another major storm and add to the toll extracted by Katrina on the US Gulf Coast.</p><p>In the longer term, however, interest rates may continue to rise because of Katrina and Rita. Criticised for the poor federal response to the disaster, US President George W Bush is throwing in US $200 billion to revive disaster-hit areas. This will not only provide a good deal of economic stimulus, but also add to the US budget deficit - factors that Fed policy makers will consider in their assessment of the economy. And with stronger growth and bigger deficits, interest rates are more likely to go up than down.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H0K-GVC0-0002-M371-00000-00<published>2005-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:19:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SINGAPORE</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Petrol prices go up by 9cents a litre;<br/>Hike to $1.927 coincides with crude oil's spike to US$70 a barrel</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Ronnie Lim</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE spiking of oil prices above US$70 a barrel yesterday coincided with petrol pump prices here jumping another nine cents to almost $2 a litre for the most popular 98 octane grade.</p><p nitf:lede="true">This is the fourth consecutive petrol pump price jump in two months, as prices first rose by nine cents on June 23, six cents on July 15, and eight cents on Aug 5. This means that petrol prices have jumped 32 cents a litre, or 15 per cent.</p><p>ExxonMobil - the biggest player with 77 out of 215 stations here - started the ball rolling, announcing in the afternoon that it would adjust its pumps from 6pm yesterday, raising the pump price of popular 98 octane grade to $1.927 a litre. The price of diesel remains the same.</p><p>It said that the petrol price increase was 'primarily due to high crude oil and wholesale petrol prices'. 'The price of crude oil is at record high levels. In the past year, retail prices have not kept pace with the sharp increase in wholesale product prices. We have tried, for as long as we can, to shield our customers from this increase.'</p><p>As of yesterday afternoon, other oil companies said that they were not adjusting prices as yet, including for competitive reasons, but were monitoring the situation.</p><p>Shell's premium grade V-Power - a 98 octane grade petrol, but which uses a base fuel similar to that in Formula One racing - costs $1.93. Caltex has a similar top grade in its Platinum petrol.</p><p>An industry official said that wholesale petrol prices - on which pump prices are based - have been going up steadily. And companies usually adjust their pump prices if the upward movement is sustained.</p><p>Oil consultant Ong Eng Tong agreed that wholesale petrol prices have shot up in the last month. 'Gasoline prices have risen faster than crude. 92 octane petrol costs US$74 a barrel, or up about US$10 in a month, and is likely to go up to US$76 today, following crude oil's spike to US $70 a barrel.'</p><p>Crude oil futures surged past US$70 a barrel for the first time yesterday as Hurricane Katrina hurtled towards the heart of US oil and refinery operations in the Gulf of Mexico, shutting down an estimated one million barrels of refining capacity.</p><p>More than 40 per cent of all US oil production in the Gulf was reportedly closed down due to the hurricane, with the total expected to rise significantly as more operators report affected production to the US government.</p><p>Mr Ong said that the rise in wholesale petrol prices here was due to several factors. China, which has reported shortages, reduced exports of petrol, while Indonesia also started buying in the market recently.</p><p>On the impact of US$70 a barrel for oil here, he expects that the price of diesel to also go up, affecting buses and taxis. Jet fuel is also likely to cost more, impacting airlines. Fuel oil, used by power stations, has also gone up by about 15 per cent, dragging natural gas prices along. This means electricity rates are likely to go up soon as well.</p><p>'While US$70 oil was due to hurricane Katrina, once that passes, the price may drop back again, although it will likely stay above US$65,' Mr Ong said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
